title: Timeline visualisation

story.name: The story begins...
story.highlightText: Designs begin for a research farm at North Wyke in Devon
story.description: A number of surveys were carried out over a period of two years, to inform the design of the farm. This included the division of the land into 15 runoff catchments, and gaining planning permission for the necessary construction.

story.name: Drainage Survey is carried out
story.description: The existing open ditch network was surveyed.

story.name: Topographic Survey is carried out
story.description: This involved a 15m gridded GPS ground level survey of the proposed platform fields.

story.name: Hydrological Designs are carried out
story.description: The design required identification of how catchments could be hydrologically isolated in terms of surface water. This took into consideration groundwater interactions, and recommended flow monitoring stations locations and specifications.

story.name: Flood Defence Consent is obtained
story.highlightText: A range of surveys were carried out to determine the environmental impact of the platform.
story.description: Flood Defence Consent is received from the UK Environment Agency. This is necessary to obtain Planning Consent

story.name: Revised flow estimates
story.description: The flow data was updated to accurately determine the hydrological monitoring design.

story.name: Badger Survey
story.description: This involved describing and evaluating badger status, and identifying both impacts and mitigation of the proposed works. Necessary for gaining Planning Consent

story.name: Habitat and Protected Species Survey
story.description: An Extended Phase 1 Habitat and Protected Species Survey was conducted to identify records relating to bats and other notable species, and to search for field signs of protected species, or habitats that could support them. Necessary for gaining Planning Consent

story.name: Tree Species and Condition Survey
story.description: A Tree Species and Condition Survey and Constraints Plan was conducted, in relation to Root Protection Areas. Locations, species, dimensions, age class, condition and remaining lifespan was identified, and a Protection Plan and Arboricultural Method Statement produced against inadvertent damage. Necessary for gaining Planning Consent

story.name: An Environmental Impact Assessment
story.description: This required an archaeological survey, and a plan to mitigate the groundworks. Necessary for gaining Planning Consent.

story.name: Lab facilities construction begins
story.description: During 2010, separate laboratories were created to handle, soil, herbage, air and water, to facilitate efficient workflows and ensure quality control across samples.

story.name: Planning Consent is received
story.highlightText: Planning consent is given and construction begins
story.description: Planning consent was given for construction of the farm platform. The construction began with the laying of drainage, construction of flumes, and fencing of the platform fields

story.name: French Drains and Flumes are constructed
story.description: 9.2km of French drains were constructed across the farm, primarily along proposed field boundary lines. Theses lead first to confluence pits, then on to sampling pits and individually sized open channel flow nozzles (H-flumes) at the catchment outlets.

story.name: Fencing and tracks are constructed
story.description: Once the French drains had been laid the fields were fenced to avoid damage or contamination by grazing animals.

story.name: Mains electricity and the fibre-optic infrastructure are laid
story.description: Each flume was supplied with mains electric power and a fibre optic cable-based data telemetry system. These services total over 5km in length.

story.name: Field events data collection begins
story.description: The collection of field events data begins. Field events include farming activities such as ploughing, fertilising, and forage harvesting (cutting).

story.name: Flume cabins are constructed
story.description: 15 flume cabins were constructed across the farm, one for each sub-catchment of the three farmlets.

story.name: Livestock data collection begins
story.description: The collection of livestock data began, including measurement of animal weights and locations.

story.name: Data sensors and telemetry equipment installed
story.description: Measuring equipment was installed in the flume cabins.

story.name: Baseline Measuring Period begins
story.highlightText: The baseline measuring period begins, with the platform managed as a single system
story.description: During the baseline measuring period, all farm platform fields are managed as permanent pasture-based livestock systems with no separate treatments as yet for the farmlets.

story.name: Soil moisture data collection begins
story.description: Measurements began from Soil Moisture Stations (SMS). There is one SMS per catchment (15 in total) and they are located approximately centrally within the fields.

story.name: Water flow and properties data collection commences
story.highlightText: Measurement of water flow and water properties begins in each catchment.
story.description: Water flow and water properties measurements began in each of the farm's 15 catchment areas using bubble flow meters in each flume.

story.name: Separate management of the three farmlets begins
story.highlightText: The farm is separated into three farmlet systems
story.description: The baseline data collection period ended and the transition to individual management of three farmlets began. This required the removal of one field, Top Burrows, from the farm platform, to even up the farmlets. The green farmlet remained as untreated permanent pasture (unimproved by inorganic fertilisers). The blue farmlet was defined as pasture with increased legume use (for biological nitrogen fixation), and the red as pasture with planned reseeding of innovative grass varieties).

story.name: Dedicated meteorological intruments installed
story.description: Precipitation, air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed and wind direction are measured at 15 minute intervals.  These are co-located next to UK Meteorological Office instruments that have been hosted on site since 1981, located in centrally in the platform site in Top Burrows.

story.name: Meteorological data collection
story.description: Collection began of precipitation, air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and wind direction data, measured at 15 minute intervals, for whole site.

story.name: Reseeding Red Catchment 2
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 2 (Great Field) with perennial ryegrass, was carried out.

story.name: Reseeding Red Catchment 15
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 15 (Longlands East) with festulolium, was carried out.

story.name: Reseeding Blue Catchment 8
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 8 (Higher Wyke Moor, Middle Wyke Moor) with perennial ryegrass and white clover was carried out

story.name: Reseeding Blue Catchment 14
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 14 (Longlands North) with festulolium and white clover was carried out

story.name: Additional French drains laid
story.description: New drains were added to divert the removed Top Burrows field drainage away from Catchment/Flume 4.

story.name: Top Burrows removed
story.description: Top Burrows field (green farmlet, Catchment 4) is removed from the Farm Platform, to keep farmlet size consistent.

story.name: Boundary change to Burrows
story.description: The eastern boundary of Burrows with the removed Top Burrows field is altered, with Burrows being consequently slightly reduced in area.

story.name: Dedicated cattle housing
story.description: Three new cattle buildings were constructed at the North Wyke Rowden site during winter 2013/2014, providing dedicated housing, silage clamps and farmyard manure middens for each of the three farmlets

story.name: Solar radiation sensor added
story.description: Solar radiation sensor added to the meteorological site

story.name: Reseeding Red Catchment 3
story.highlightText: Three new cattle buildings started in 2013 are completed. Reseeding continues.
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 3 (Poor Field, Ware Park) with perennial ryegrass. The blue and red farmlets will be ploughed and reseeded over a 28 month period, lasting until the end of the 2015 grazing season.

story.name: Reseeding Blue Catchment 9
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 9 (Dairy South, Dairy Corner) with perennial ryegrass and white clover

story.name: Soil monitoring station added
story.description: A CEH COSMOS-UK soil monitoring station was installed on Catchment 2

story.name: Phosphax analysers
story.description: Phosphax analysers measured both total and ortho-phosphate from here onwards.

story.name: Pluvio rain gauge added
story.description: Added to the central meteorological site to complement the 15 tipping buckets on the farm catchments

story.name: Soil moisture sensors replaced
story.description: The Adcon A51760 model sensors were replaced with the A51730 model.

story.name: Reseeding Red Catchment 1
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 1 (Pecketsford, Little Pecketsford) with perennial ryegrass

story.name: Reseeding Red Catchment 10
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 10 (Lower Wheaty) with perennial ryegrass

story.name: Reseeding Blue Catchment 7
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 7 (Lower Wyke Moor) with perennial ryegrass and white clover

story.name: Reseeding Blue Catchment 11
story.description: Ploughing and reseeding of Catchment 11 (Dairy East) with perennial ryegrass and white clover

story.name: Orchard Dean is split into two fields
story.highlightText: Orchard Dean is split into two fields
story.description: Orchard Dean is split into two fields: Orchard Dean North, and Orchard Dean South (both part of the Green farmlet, Catchment 5). This achieved an even seven fields per farmlet, to facilitate comparisons across systems when triplet management (cattle grazing, sheep grazing and cutting) came into operation in 2016

story.name: Pressure transducers installed
story.description: These replaced bubble flow meters in the catchments.

story.name: Triplet management begins
story.highlightText: Triplet management (rotation of cattle grazing, sheep grazing and cutting) of the farmlets begins
story.description: The triplet system for management of the farmlets comes fully into operation during 2016, with the aim of making comparisons between farmlet enterprise management of equivalent areas. This was not always achievable prior to 2016 due to the reseeding phases. Cattle grazing, sheep grazing and cutting are rotated according to the 'enterprise' allocated to each field in a farmlet.

story.name: More equipment is replaced and upgraded
story.description: YSI 6600V2 multi-parameter sonde upgaded to YSI Exo.Turbidity units changed from NTU to FNU. New loggers installed, with all this replacement equipment operative by the end of October. Flume loggers were changed from Adcon A723 to OTT netDL for data transfer via the fibre optic network.

story.name: Virtual fence lines identified
story.highlightText: Virtual fence lines are identified to allow fields to be split
story.description: Several virtual fence lines per field were identified by GPS, allowing for fields to be temporarily split into (typically two) sections using movable fences. This was to facilitate management of the areas used for grazing and silage production (identified as 'field strips' in the Data Portal).

story.name: Phosphax instrumentation added to Catchment 3
story.description: Phosphax instrumentation (phosphorus analyser) installed in Catchment 3 flume (red farmlet), in addition to those in Catchments 5 (green farmlet), 8 (blue farmlet and 2 (red farmlet)

story.name: Blue Catchment 14 is oversown
story.description: Catchment 14 (Longlands North) was oversown with a white clover mixture

story.name: The Orr Small Ruminant Facility is constructed
story.description: Dedicated sheep facility, separated into farmlets (not previously possible) for winter housing, with further separation for subgroups so ewes may have nutritional requirements optimised depending on number of lambs carried. Some pens are suitable for goats. The facility also includes 24 biocontrol units for feed intake studies

story.name: Second system change period begins
story.highlightText: The red system is transitioned to arable
story.description: This represents a second period of system changes to the farm platform. The Red farmlet is converted to arable with planned rotation of winter wheat, winter wheat, oats and beans. The former red farmlet cattle are housed until finishing in a new fourth indoor farmlet, known as the Brown farmlet. From here on, outdoor cattle and sheep production is carried out solely on the Green and Blue farmlets.

story.name: Red farmlet transitions to arable
story.description: Sheep and lambs grazing the Red farmlet were removed from the system, and the cattle were transferred to housing. The existing grass sward of the entire red farmlet was sprayed off, ploughed and sown with winter wheat

story.name: Brown system 4 is introduced
story.description: The Brown farmlet consists of permanently housed cattle for evaluation of more intensive finishing.

story.name: Transition to twin management begins
story.description: The former triplet enterprise management system, transtioned to a twin system for comparisons between the Green and Blue farmlets after the Red system was transitioned to arable

story.name: Catchment 1 fields are combined
story.description: Catchment 1 fields, Pecketsford and Little Pecketsford were combined into one field, known as Pecketsford(whole).

story.name: Red farmlet sown with winter wheat
story.highlightText: Sowing of crops on the red farmlet begins
story.description: Entire red farmlet sown with winter wheat

story.name: Red farmlet sown with winter oats
story.description: Entire red farmlet sown with winter oats

story.name: Red farmlet sown with winter wheat
story.description: Entire red farmlet was sown with winter wheat, but using a minimum tillage (no plough) method.

story.name: No more events for now
story.description: Check back later for more information

comments: Dates in story events refer to completion of events. If not specified then the entire month is included, which may be or not be the case - or  the (start of?) the final day of the relevant month. - depending on the event? Still need to rake through the datasets  to get correct start and end dates for collection of all the kinds of data.
